Abstract: Fear of "scanxiety" (a feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease about an imminent CT scan forcancer) is experienced by many cancer patients and survivors, especially lung cancer patients.Research suggests that scanxiety and fear of cancer reoccurrence are prominent and overlookedsymptoms. Although psychological interventions exist for health anxiety and scanxiety, it isunclear if they fit lung cancer patients' needs. Therefore, we will qualitatively assess lung cancerpatients' and survivors' scanxiety. Additionally, we will explore how patients and survivors cope(e.g., through social support and therapy) with their scanxiety and fears. Lung cancer patientsand survivors will complete an online questionnaire. The study will reveal the gap between lungcancer patients and survivors' scanxiety and the support they received.
AuthorBlock: Christine Qiong Wu. Manitoba Lung Cancer Support Group, MB, Canada
SearchResultBody: ADV201. Patient Reported Needs for Coping with Scanxiety of Lung Cancer
Title: Patient Reported Needs for Coping with Scanxiety of Lung Cancer

Abstract: The Karmanos Cancer Advocacy Program (KCAP) at the Karmanos Cancer Institute in conjunction with Wayne State University is dedicated to the prevention and cure of cancer. Our goal is to develop and promote a formal means for active patient advocacy; to facilitate cancer clinical trials awareness and accrual throughout local and state communities; and to provide a forum for cancer education about the state of cancer prevention screening, treatment, research, clinical trials and survivorship. The Karmanos Cancer Advocacy Program (KCAP) began in 2018 under the leadership of Dr. Elisabeth Heath as a partnership between patients and the research community. KCAP in an extension of the Prostate Cancer Advocacy Group (PCAP) established in 2010. The successful PCAP advocacy model expanded to include all cancers. KCAP trains survivors and their family members to help support Karmanos cancer research initiatives, review grant proposals for research studies, and become involved in volunteer led action groups that affect the future of cancer care. KCAP advocates have attended a year-long didactic training designed to promote survivor engagement in investigator driven research. The course was created for the advocates to be well prepared and empowered to engage with Karmanos Cancer Institute researchers and help direct future cancer research. Advocates develop grant-reviewing skills and began providing much needed feedback for internal and external grant review study sections. KCAP advocates participate in panel discussions and seminars on issues affecting cancer research, join advocacy groups, meet with government officials to discuss issues impacting cancer care and more. KCAP advocates have participated in events with American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network (ASC-CAN) speaking with state legislators about issues influencing cancer in the state. KCAP Advocates are active in the Karmanos clinic areas and provide cancer awareness and education outreach to the community through presentations to community groups or education during health fairs and other outreach events.
AuthorBlock: William Winkler. Karmanos Cancer Institute, Detroit, MI
SearchResultBody: ADV202. Karmanos Cancer Institute Cancer Advocacy Program (KCAP)
Title: Karmanos Cancer Institute Cancer Advocacy Program (KCAP)

Abstract: The poster features statistics on myeloma in the Black American Community and references the goals of the HealthTree Foundation in reducing disparities and bringing awareness to myeloma. It explains the foundation's REACH program for patient and healthcare team education. It also lists the foundation's partnerships and traces patient experience with access barriers and barriers in clinical research.
AuthorBlock: Valarie Traynham. Health Tree Foundation, Aurora, IL
SearchResultBody: ADV203. Multiple Myeloma and the Black American Community
Title: Multiple Myeloma and the Black American Community

Abstract: The poster delves into the topic of cancer and pregnancy and the impact on treatment plans.
AuthorBlock: Terlisa Sheppard. For the Breast of Us, Jacksonville, FL
Title: Cancer Diagnosis During Pregnancy

Abstract: While some patients fully embrace and appreciate access to test results as they become available, those who may be less informed or who are receiving a diagnosis for the first time may find reading results without the guidance from their oncologist or physician to be fear-inducing and anxiety provoking. Patients aren''t the only ones impacted by this new law. Physicians also have concerns about the impact of patients who misread the results, receive results they are not emotionally prepared for, or who experience high degrees of stress and anxiety without available support at night, on weekends, or other times they are not able to reach their doctor right away. What’s missing is a process to help patients prepare for viewing results. Combining my experience as a patient advocate, my years of working with cancer survivors and caregivers as a coach, and my professional training gives me a unique perspective for exploring the concerns, needs, and the strategic solutions that can be integrated to overcome the challenges being created by the Cures Act. The poster will highlight both sides of the experience - those who heartily embrace immediate access to their results and those who find it anxiety-provoking along with identifying gaps in the process and strategies that could improve the overall experience for patients/caregivers and their physicians without interfering with those who want to know right away.
SearchResultBody: ADV205. Access on Demand - Understanding the Impact of the 21st Century Cures Act & Addressing Process Gaps
Title: Access on Demand - Understanding the Impact of the 21st Century Cures Act & Addressing Process Gaps

Abstract: The goal of the Powell-Drescher Ovarian Cancer Research Foundation is to foster breakthrough ovarian cancer research that will meaningfully improve ovarian cancer outcomes. We believe that this breakthrough research requires close collaboration between individuals who experience the disease and scientists who are trying to address the problem. A major obstacle is that advocates - ovarian cancer survivors, patients, family members, caregivers, previvors, or other persons touched by ovarian cancer - who bring the experience of living with ovarian cancer do not typically interact with the scientists who are working on its prevention, detection, treatment and/or cure. We intend to address this obstacle through a range of innovative programs and projects as by working together, the physician and the patient, the scientist and the survivor, have the power to change the statistics
AuthorBlock: Susun Lindley Livingston. Powell-Drescher Ovarian Cancer Research Foundation, Seattle, WA
SearchResultBody: ADV206. To power the future of ovarian cancer research by endowing funds and championing collaboration between scientist and survivor - Scientist Perspective
Title: To power the future of ovarian cancer research by endowing funds and championing collaboration between scientist and survivor - Scientist Perspective

AuthorBlock: Sabrina Mayhew. Michigan Breast Cancer Coalition, Birmingham, MI
SearchResultBody: ADV207. The Perspectives of African American Breast Cancer Survivor Advocates on Research and Clinical Trials
Title: The Perspectives of African American Breast Cancer Survivor Advocates on Research and Clinical Trials

Abstract: The Lobular Breast Cancer Alliance Inc. (LBCA) is committed to raising awareness of the distinctive characteristics of invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) and promoting and funding ILC research. Comprising 15% of all breast cancers, ILC tumors often form in a linear, sometimes diffuse fashion both within the breast and in metastatic sites, making them difficult to diagnose, monitor, and treat. LBCA surveyed individuals living with metastatic ILC (mILC) about their experiences with detection and monitoring of mILC. Methods: LBCA conducted an anonymous, online survey of persons living with mILC using SurveyMonkey. The survey was shared with LBCA newsletter subscribers, sister organizations, and via social media. Survey questions asked about metastatic site locations, imaging and monitoring modalities, and patient experience with disease progression and clinician discussions about mILC.
AuthorBlock: Gitte Henssel Joergensen. Lobular Breast Cancer Alliance, Conventry, CT
SearchResultBody: ADV208. Lobular Breast Cancer Alliance Inc. Survey of Individuals With Metastatic Invasive Lobular Carcinoma
Title: Lobular Breast Cancer Alliance Inc. Survey of Individuals With Metastatic Invasive Lobular Carcinoma

Abstract: The three pillars of the Twisted Pink mission and why they are important to bring early-stage survivors and people living with metastatic breast cancer together to fund bold breakthroughs in research and awareness of the disease.
Title: Support, Research and Hope

Abstract: The poster describes the two projects forca-strength against cancer (a UK-registered charity) is running to help those affected by cancer in the local community. These initiatives, which otherwise wouldn't be available to cancer patients, are proving to be invaluable. The funds for both of these initiatives are raised in the community for the community! Since their inception, they have positively affected hundreds of patients and their immediate families. Project 1 - "Nourish...by forca" - offering two free meals to take home to those receiving treatment at the local hospital. This means the patient (and their immediate family) don't have to think about cooking for that day and the day after. Meals can also be frozen to be used another day, when energy levels perhaps aren't optimal. Project 2 - "Support...by forca" - offering free compression bras at two local hospitals to women who will undergo breast surgery due to a cancer diagnosis. These highly functional garments designed to aid recovery after surgery have been a godsend to many women who, otherwise, would most likely not invest in such a valuable garment.
SearchResultBody: ADV210. Practical help for those affected by cancer
Title: Practical help for those affected by cancer

Abstract: Addressing Health Inequities in Pennsylvania will provide data sets from a study that was released by the Pennsylvania Cancer Coalition which is interconnected to the PA Prostate Cancer Coalition. The data will show how African American men are diagnosed with cancer along with eight other health conditions at a significantly higher rate when compared to the general population of the state.
AuthorBlock: Brian Alan Jones. Pennsylvania Prostate Cancer Coalition, Harrisburg, PA
SearchResultBody: ADV211. Addressing Health Inequities in Pennsylvania
Title: Addressing Health Inequities in Pennsylvania

Abstract: It is well known that many cancer patients/survivors face a deluge of information overload. The process can begin before the actual diagnosis, beginning with the plethora of testing that facilitates the actual diagnosis. This means that many patients are already in overload when they receive their cancer diagnosis. Most places offer tips for how patients can manage this, but there are also mechanisms that can be put in place to help patients navigate their diagnosis, treatment, and follow up care and lessening the feeling of overwhelmed on the care delivery side. This poster explores options for inclusion into small and large practices.
AuthorBlock: Blair Coe Schweiger. National Cervical Coalition, Waco, TX
SearchResultBody: ADV212. Information Overload: Helping cancer patients navigate the process
Title: Information Overload: Helping cancer patients navigate the process

Abstract: Lung cancer patients are living longer with new treatments. An analysis from 2019 showed that despite 25% of cancer deaths in Canada resulting from lung cancer, the research funding was a paltry 6% of all cancer research funding. The largest amount of funding at 25% is for breast cancer, though it only accounts for about 6% of cancer deaths. Canadian cancer research funding is broken down using Common Scientific Outline (CSO) into six basic categories: 1 - Biology 2 - Etiology 3 - Prevention 4 - Early detection, diagnosis, prognosis 5 - Treatment 6 - Cancer control, survivorship and outcomes. Data from the Canadian Cancer Research Alliance (CCRA) were used to explore the funding in Canada. We used the data from CCRA to create a model for the funding trends for the last fifteen years. Comparison with research funding for all cancers was used as a proxy to suggest best places to look for funding opportunities. Lung cancer research is 6% of the funding received for all cancer research. Using this as an expectation, it is immediately apparent that Prevention at 24% in the third period (2015-2019) of the analysis accounts for the majority of lung cancer research spending and indeed was a major component of overall cancer research spending. Early detection research spending is also found to be increasing. This is important as most lung cancer is detected at a late stage and accounts for the extremely high mortality rate of this cancer. The other four categories of research however are below the average in the analysis indicating under-spending relative to other cancer types. Stable but low levels of funding for basic biology research around lung cancer have limited the understanding of lung cancer. In the remaining three areas, funding has declined over the last fifteen years. There is a growing realization that there is more than carcinogenic tobacco smoke at work in causing lung cancer. More research into the etiology of lung cancer is required. Treatment for lung cancer has been revolutionized by immunotherapies, targeted therapies, radiotherapy techniques, and surgical approaches. But again in comparison to other cancers, research in lung cancer treatment have been underfunded. Finally, despite more and more lung cancer patients surviving there is a decline in cancer control, survivorship, and the outcomes of research funding. Next steps in this process beyond the obvious lobbying for more money for lung cancer research are to begin to establish patient priorities for where the money should be directed.
SearchResultBody: ADV213. If I had a Billion Dollars - Exploring Funding Gaps and Possibilities in Lung Cancer Research Funding
Title: If I had a Billion Dollars - Exploring Funding Gaps and Possibilities in Lung Cancer Research Funding

Abstract: The poster shows how the legacy of a patient diagnosed with a brain tumor has ignited a team of passionate individuals to serve as catalysts to make a difference in the field of brain cancer research. The poster highlights unique ways of bringing together scientists, patient advocates, and funding agencies to serve as the beacon of hope for patients suffering from this terrible disease.
AuthorBlock: Shandra Koler. Sontag Foundation, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL
SearchResultBody: ADV214. Go Bold: Accelerating Science through Collaborative Partnerships
Title: Go Bold: Accelerating Science through Collaborative Partnerships
